roleset.name: to amount to or come to an average, compute an average, calculating/finding/creating a mean, median or mode, computed mean
roleset.note: AVERAGE-V NOTES: Frames file for 'average' based on WSJ. Member of Vncls multiply-108-3. (from average.01-v)
AVERAGING-N NOTES: Added by Julia based on BOLT, average.01. Corresponds to VNcls multiply-108-3. (from averaging.01-n)

role.descr: numerical value of the average (or whatever final form it takes)

example.name: average-v: non-agentive
example.text: In October , the busiest month of the year so far , daily volume averaged roughly 145 million shares .
example.arg: In October , the busiest month of the year so far ,

example.name: average-v: with Arg3
example.text: The Manhattan U.S. attorney 's office stressed [criminal cases]*-1 from 1980 to 1987 , [*-1]averaging 43 for every 100,000 adults .

example.name: average-v: agentive
example.text: On the civil side , the Manhattan prosecutor filed an average of only 11 cases for every 100,000 adults during the same period ; the San Francisco U.S. attorney averaged 79 .

example.name: average-v: transitive
example.text: That is in part because of the effect of [*]-2 having [*-2]to average the number of shares outstanding , she said [0] [*T*-1] .

example.name: averaging-n: financial strategy. Arg1
example.text: Read up on Pound Cost Averaging .

roleset.name: having a normal skill level
roleset.note: AVERAGE-J NOTES: Added by Julia. (from average.02-j)

example.name: average-j: both args
example.text: The first is a master a gaming, the latter is average at doing all things.

roleset.name: normal, in the range of mean, meadian or mode
roleset.note: AVERAGE-J NOTES: Added by Julia based on average-v.01. (from average.01-j)

example.name: average-j: arg1
example.text: By the time we get them , their effect and value will only be average .
example.arg: By the time we get them

roleset.name: experiencing or having an average
roleset.note: AVERAGING-N NOTES: Added by Julia. No VNcls. (from averaging.02-n)
